figureCitation.captionText: FIGURE 6. Morphological features of Orophyllus grandivalvatus sp. nov. A) frons in fronto-ventral view B) head and pronotum in dorsal view C) pronotum in lateral view D) sterna in ventral view E) end of the left tegmina in ventral view F) left hind femora in dorsal view G) apex of male abdomen in dorsal view. H) male subgenital plate in ventral view I) female subgenital plate in ventral view J) female ovipositor in lateral view. A, B, C, D, F, G, H: male; E, I, J: female. Scale bar= 2mm.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6. Morphological features of
Orophyllus grandivalvatus
sp. nov.
A) frons in fronto-ventral view B) head and pronotum in dorsal view C) pronotum in lateral view D) sterna in ventral view E) end of the left tegmina in ventral view F) left hind femora in dorsal view G) apex of male abdomen in dorsal view. H) male subgenital plate in ventral view I) female subgenital plate in ventral view J) female ovipositor in lateral view. A, B, C, D, F, G, H: male; E, I, J: female. Scale bar= 2mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Female : Larger than male. Generally, the tip of tegmina recurved and pointed ( Fig. 6E , Fig. 8 ), C and Sc area broader than female of other species ( Fig. 8 ). Epiproct longer than wide, oval, with a shallow notch at the end. Styli conical and long. The basal half of the dorsal valves of the ovipositor straight, the distal half narrowing from the base to the end. Base of the ovipositor yellowish-brown, then gradually darkened ( Fig. 6J ). Subgenital plate as in
O . nigrisartorius
, a triangular wide notch in the center of the rear edge, with rounded corners on both sides ( Fig. 6I ).

Etymology: Species name
grandivalvatus
relates to the ovipositor being long and robust.
